newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Malaysia executive sees more Pakistan investment.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia executive sees more Pakistan investment.

text.p: A Malaysian power company executive said on Thursday he had found positive attitude in Pakistan's new government to encourage Malaysian investment.

Ahmad Tajuddin Ali, executive chairman and chief executive officer of Malaysia's Tenaga National Berhad (TNB) power utility, said in an interview more Malaysian investors would be attracted to Pakistan after the completion of the $500 million TNB-led Liberty Power project here.

Ali, who held talks with Pakistan Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz and other officials on Wednesday, said he was encouraged by "the positive attitude of the government towards Malaysia's efforts to promote investment in Pakistan".
He said over 75 percent work on the $256 million first phase of the two-phase 460-megawatt Liberty project in the southern province of Sindh had been completed in the past 14 months.
With the completion of the entire project and "beginning of reasonable returns on the investment, more and more Malaysian investors will be attracted to Pakistan", he said.

TNB is the single largest shareholder in Liberty with 40 percent shares. Other partners are Union Texas and Entergy of the United States, Britain's Commonwealth Development Corporation, Asia Infrastructure Development Company owned by the Japanese government and major industrial firms, and U.S.-based Infrastructure Capital Group.
